messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@y..., "C. Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@c...> wrote:

PG: What I meant by "hold over" was that was what was desired in
the past with T.O. I am not so sure it would be necessary in a new
script relatively closely connected to people's current speech
patterns.

Standardization in printed material does not preclude regional
spelling in informal communication.

> PG: If on some remote island, you could introduce six year olds
to QS from the beginning, I have no doubt their reading speed would
match and probably exceed TO.

SB: I agree. It is just a matter of practice.

> PG: I do not understand the foregoing. Tell us more about
the "1755 standardization." Who did it and by what authority? Are
you referring to the publication of Johnson's dictionary? It seems
to me that when such a standardization took place, it would have
been the perfect time to correct the differences between spoken and
written English that existed then. Or was Johnson's point that the
divergence is inevitable anyway, so we might as well give up on the
idea of keeping an alphabet in sync with people's pronunciation?

SB: Paul, remember that in the 16c English had some very radical
shifts and changes in pronunciation as well as an influx of new
words and spellings.

There were also major differences between the speech of London and
those in the north of England. In fact, the dialects of London were
so great that they were often difficult to understand.

Compared to Spain's Nebrija, Dr. Johnson was rather timid but then
he was facing a different situation. Nebrija transcribed the
language of the royal court. For some reason, this was not as clear
cut in English. The Royal Society had been founded a 100 years
earlier and had taken up the problem of language and its written
form -- but they did nothing. Wilkens devised an adequate way of
phonemically representing English but it was used more for
cryptography.

One would presume that there was a king's English and a prestige
dialect that could be described phonemically but no one followed the
example of Spain.

Steve
